--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote: 
> Yes Derek you make a good point.  The interaction
> between
> complexification and simplification in NEAT has not
> been
> well studied.  However, we have studied
> simplification in
> isolation: We ran experiments where we started with
> large fully-
> connected topologies and then let them simplify by
> removing genes.
> This was far less powerful than starting minimally
> and 
> complexifying, although it was interesting.  You
> tended to get 
> spurts of several improvements in a row after every
> few 
> simplifications, but the improvements tended to be
> miniscule 
> compared to the ones you get with complexification. 

Yeah, I think you mentioned that you had done
something like this experimentally.  I probably would
have expected this approach to be less powerful than
starting minimally and complexifying, but by how much,
I wouldn't have guessed...I'm sure it depends on many
other factors, as well.

I would intuitively think that simplification would
work best in cases where either good solutions
existed, but were overly complex and inefficient, or
in cases where features that were once adaptive have
become unnecessary, or vestigial.

> In any case, if you start out minimally, and
> complexify *and* 
> simplify (albeit at a lower rate than complexifying)
> that could
> be pretty interesting.  And it should work as you
> say- speciation
> will protect simplifications just as it does
> complexifications.

I definitely want to do some experimentation along
these lines.

I'm guessing that simplification isn't all that
important in small input/output domains.  NEAT does a
wonderful job of mitigating against bloat and ensuring
that throughout the process simpler solutions prevail.
 

But my instinct tells me that in very high
input/output domains, efficiency is going to be even
more important, and that simplification may play an
important role.

For instance, I don't think simplification will be an
important attribute when evolving Tic-Tac-Toe players,
but in order to tackle Go, I think there may need to
be aspects of the GA that allow for underutilized
portions of the network to be pruned out by evolution.
 I don't know, though.

I think it would be very interesting to compare the
impact of simplification between two similar domains
in which one has an order of magnitude more
inputs/outputs.  Hopefully I'll be able to look at
this within the next 6 months or so. :)

Derek
